_prev_prog_3.Description: Anheuser-Busch has implemented a comprehensive program to prevent accidental releases. Designed to reduce both the likelihood and severity of releases of ammonia, this program integrates technology, procedures and management practices. This prevention program ensures that safe design principles and practices are followed for the brewery ammonia system and related projects by properly managing changes to the system, as well as ensuring proper operation, maintenance and control of hazards.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The purpose of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program is to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances and minimize the severity of those releases if they should occur.  The Anheuser-Busch, Inc. Los Angeles Brewery (AB Los Angeles Brewery) developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) to address the CalARP Program requirements (California Health and Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Sections 2735-2785).  CalARP requires that RMPs be updated at least every five years.  On behalf of the AB Los Angeles Brewery, ERM-West, Inc. (ERM) has prepared this RMP update to satisfy that requirement.  The RMP is submitted to the Los Angeles Fire Department, who function as the Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA) for the City of Los Angeles.  This RMP covers the anhydrous ammonia used as a refrigerant at the brewery in quantities exceeding the Federal and California quantity thresholds of 10,000 pounds:

?    Federal:  United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Title 40, Parts 9 and 68, Tables 1 and 2

?    California: CalARP Regulation - California Code of Regulations [CCR] Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 Section 2770.5 (Table 3). 

The facility is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The facility utilizes trained staff, modern equipment to monitor the facility, and numerous safeguards to effectively and safely use ammonia for refrigeration purposes.

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The AB Los Angeles Brewery has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The AB Los Angeles Brewery has developed and implements Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency

Response Programs to enhance employee and public safety.

The facility has implemented a Prevention Program for the anhydrous ammonia process, as required by the RMP rule.    The program provisions are specifically intended to minimize the probability and/or consequences of accidental releases from the facility.  The facility Prevention Program is a living program that is updated as required to reflect facility changes.

Per the CalARP management system requirements (CCR ? 2735.6) the Prevention Program includes:

?    A management system to oversee the implementation of the CalARP Program elements.

?    A qualified person has been designated with overall responsibility for the development and integration of the CalARP Program elements.

For the AB Los Angeles Brewery, Mr. Christopher Harden (EHS&S Manager) is the CalARP Coordinator, and has overall responsibility for the development and integration of the program.  Other EHS&S Managers assist Mr. Harden in program updates and implementation.

FACILITY OVERVIEW AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The AB Los Angeles Brewery located at 15800 Roscoe Boulevard, Van Nuys, California.  The brewery originally opened at this location in 1954.  The facility occupies approximately 95 acres and operates an approximately 1,700,00 square foot (total floor space) brewery.  The brewery utilizes approximately 160,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant to keep the products at their desired temperatures.  The ammonia refrigerations system includes, but is not limited to ammonia receivers, transfer pumps, compressors, condensers, heat exchangers, air conditioning units, and piping.  

No other substances at the AB Los Angeles Brewery exceeds their respective Federal or California threshold quantities.

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The CalARP program has different requirements based on the complexity, accident history, and potential impact of releases of the regulated substance

.  These requirements are divided into three levels:  Program 1, Program 2, and Program 3, with Program 3 being the strictest.  

The worst-case release scenario for the anhydrous ammonia process results in distance to toxic endpoints that extends past the property boundary.  Additionally, the process is subject to the federal OSHA process safety management standards of Section 1910.119 of Title 29 of CFR or Section 5189 of Title 8 of CCR.  Thus, Program Level 3 requirements apply to the anhydrous ammonia process.

The CalARP Program requires Program Level 3 facilities to develop an RMP that includes the following key elements:

?    2745.3 RMP Executive Summary Component 

?    2745.4 RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Component 

?    2745.5 RMP Five-year Accident History Component 

?    2745.7 RMP Program 3 Prevention Program Component

o    2760.1 Process Safety Information

o    2760.2 Process Hazard Analysis [PHA]

o    2760.3 Operating Procedures 

o    2760.4 Training 

o    2760.5 Mechanical Integrity

o    2760.6 Management of Change 

o    2760.7 Pre-Startup Review

o    2760.8 Compliance Audits 

o    2760.9 Incident Investigation

o    2760.10 Employee Participation

o    2760.11 Hot Work Permit 

o    2760.12 Contractors 

?    2745.8 RMP Emergency Response Program Component

?    2745.9 RMP Certification

The AB Los Angeles Brewery has recognized the inherent potential risks associated with the storage and use of ammonia and has structured its safety programs to manage these risks.  The facility has included several safeguards in the design of the system.  Accident prevention safeguards include, but are not limited to:

?    General Safeguards:

    Personnel operating and maintaining systems undergo routine training;

    Daily and monthly inspections of equipment and process areas are conducted; 

    The facility is fenced with key card access; and

    Security patrols and video surveillance.

?    Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

    Equipment is equipped with numerous safety d

evices including, but not limited to:

?    Pressure relief valves;

?    Pressure and temperature indicators;

?    Level alarms; and

?    Redundancies.

    High visibility piping and protected from traffic;

    Emergency shutdown system, including seismic activity sensors; and

    Equipment designed to fail in the safe position.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no CalARP RMP reportable releases at the AB Los Angeles Brewery in the past 5 years that resulted in any of the following:

?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or

?    Known off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has developed an emergency response program that satisfies Section 2765.2 of the CalARP rule and also coordinates with the local fire department for emergency response.  The AB Los Angeles Brewery's emergency response program is based on OSHA's requirements for emergency action plans (8 CCR 3220) and HAZWOPER (29 CFR 1910.120). The Brewery has trained employees for emergency response and maintains an "Environmental/Safety Incident Plan" (ESIP) which has been supplied to, and discussed with, the Los Angeles City Fire Department. Annual drills are conducted for implementation of the ESIP at the brewery.  The ESIP includes emergencies such as fires, significant chemical leaks, or spills.

Brewery personnel notify local agencies when emergency response is needed. Local agencies determine if the public needs to be notified. If it is determined that the public needs to be notified, the local agencies perform the notification task.

Additionally, the AB Los Angeles Brewery has an an emergency response team (ABET) trained to respond to ammonia releases.  The ABET team members are trained to respond to various emergency situations, including responding to ammonia releases.  The ABET team members are certified to wear self-contained breathing apparatus (SCUBA).  T

he ABET conducts periodic drills, including annual joint drills with the fire department.

SAFETY MANAGEMENT AND PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The facility is committed to ensuring its operations are safe and in accordance with all RMP requirements.  These efforts include providing refresher training at least every three years, annual reviews of operating and maintenance procedures, and periodic reviews of process safety information to ensure they are up to date and accurate.  Additionally, PHAs and compliance audits are conducted per CalARP requirements to identify potential hazards and confirm the RMP is being properly implemented.

Changes recommended during the PHA and compliance audit will be evaluated for implementation to improve the overall safety of the facility.  The recommended changes can be found in the PHA and compliance audit reports, respectively.

Other changes planned to improve safety include:

Installation of ammonia sensors in strategic locations throughout the brewery and integrating the sensors with the buildings ventilation systems.
